item.title: Ukraine Takes Step Toward Joining NATO
item.description: A parliamentary vote to pursue closer ties to the West drew a sharp rebuke from Russia, which called the step counterproductive.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: France Orders Troop Reinforcements After Attacks
item.description: Security officials say they have not established any direct links between the three attacks, which have reinforced concerns about Islamic militancy.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Christian Guilleminot/Le Bien Public, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue workers aided victims in Dijon, France, on Sunday after a driver, identified as a 40-year-old man with psychiatric issues, plowed into a crowd.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Send Its First Infantry Troops to U.N. Mission in South Sudan
item.description: The move is widely seen as a sign of greater Chinese commitment to United Nations peacekeeping efforts and of Beijing’s wishes to step up protection of its commercial interests in the country.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Civilians in a United Nations-run camp for internally displaced persons in Juba, South Sudan. China plans to contribute its first infantry troops to the U.N. peacekeeping force in South Sudan next month.

item.title: Algerian Army Kills Man Behind French Beheading
item.description: In a late night operation, Algeria's army killed the leader of an Islamic State splinter group blamed for the kidnapping and beheading of a French hiker, the Ministry of Defense said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Greek Parliament’s Vote for President Moves to Decisive Round for Coalition
item.description: The voting will either enable the coalition government of the prime minister to remain in power or lead to a snap general election and new political and financial upheaval.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Ukraine Abandons Nonaligned Status
item.description: Ukraine's parliament on Tuesday voted to abandon the country's nonaligned status, a move that could be a step toward seeking membership in NATO.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ex-Official and Property Tycoon Are Sentenced in Hong Kong Graft Case
item.description: The former No. 2 official in the city government and a real estate mogul were given terms of seven and a half years and five years in prison.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Tibetan Woman Dies After Setting Herself on Fire in China
item.description: The death brought to 135 the number of Tibetans who have set themselves ablaze since 2009 to protest what many regard as government intrusion.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Taxi Ride in Xinjiang Reveals Ethnic Strains
item.description: A ride with an ethnic Han Chinese woman in the city of Karamay was a reminder of the frictions that have accompanied the economic drive in the oil-rich region of Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH M. KESSEL
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign on the dashboard indicated which forms of dress could bar a person from entering a taxi or public transportation.

item.title: Conflict Coverage Proves Deadly Job for Journalists
item.description: In its annual report, the Committee to Protect Journalists said that Syria remained the world’s deadliest country for journalists for the third consecutive year.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: United Nations Security Council Examines North Korea’s Human Rights
item.description: North Korea chose not to speak at the Council briefing, which focused largely on a United Nations inquiry that had found widespread and systematic human rights abuses.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: North Korea Loses Its Link to the Internet
item.description: While perhaps a coincidence, the failure, which lasted about 10 hours, began after President Obama said the U.S. would respond to an act of “cybervandalism” against Sony Pictures.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Korea Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, in an undated photo from a textile mill, leads a country that has fewer Internet protocol addresses than many city blocks in New York. As of Monday, Internet access was dead.

item.title: Cliff Sloan, Guantánamo Envoy, Quits Amid Delays in Prisoner Releases
item.description: Mr. Sloan, the envoy who negotiates detainee transfers from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, is resigning, dealing another blow to efforts to close the facility.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Paris Journal: A Window Onto Evolving Traditions in Paris
item.description: The Christmas window displays at Paris’s main department stores have bent obligingly with the years, reflecting a creeping — sometimes jarring — fusion of popular and consumer culture.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Christmas window at Printemps, a leading department store in Paris. A rival just down the street, Galeries Lafayette, also features elaborate displays.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: 2 Explosions Kill at Least 26
item.description: Two explosions in two northeastern Nigerian states on Monday killed at least 26 people and wounded 79, rescue and health officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Qatar Suspends News Channel Critical of Egyptian Government
item.description: The shutdown of the channel, an Egyptian affiliate of the Qatari-owned Al Jazeera network, is also a blow to what remains of the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Facebook Page Goes Dark, Angering Russia Dissidents
item.description: Members of the Russian political opposition said Facebook had capitulated to government pressure without consulting them.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Court Sides With Orangutan
item.description: An Argentine court said an orangutan that had lived for 20 years at the Buenos Aires zoo was entitled to some legal rights enjoyed by humans.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: France: 11 Hurt as Van Strikes Market
item.description: An Interior Ministry spokesman, Pierre-Henry Brandet, said the driver “deliberately crashed into the crowd.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Liberia: Soccer Star Leads Senate Race
item.description: The former soccer star George Weah appeared to have won a landslide victory in a Senate race that pitted him against the president’s son, Robert Sirleaf.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIR MacDOUGALL
